column1: Mons-en-Barœul is a commune in the Nord department in northern France.
It is a suburb of the city of Lille
column2: and is adjacent to it on the northeast. The name Mons-en-Barœul means mount in the Barœul
column3: the city is built on a slight hill; the Barœul was a former territory (see also Marcq-en-Barœul). Before the sixteenth century
column4: little is known of this county
column5: which was only rural. Plans of the eighteenth century show Mons-en-Barœul as a small village without a church
column6: with farms scattered along the high road from Lille to Roubaix. It is a former dependency of Fives
column7: a district which is now part of Lille.

column1: Michel Butor was born in Mons-en-Barœul.
